title: Goal Chain
subtitle: PROJECT Goal is the foundation — everything traces back to it
rules: Every milestone must trace to a sentence in PROJECT ## Goal

Goal text changes rarely. Milestones are set when phases are planned
`pass:` lives only in TODO — it is binary, you pass or you don't
When all `pass:` criteria pass → milestone done → phase done → DONE
Everything must pass through DONE first

title: INSTALL File

title: PROJECT File

title: RAG File

title: TODO File

rules: `phase:` and `id:` MUST match PROJECT.phase and PROJECT.id

When all tasks `done` → move to DONE, update PROJECT, start next phase

title: CI/CD Pipeline
subtitle: Tag-triggered builds from clean checkout — artifacts go to release, never manual upload
rules: All release builds from clean CI checkout — no local state
Matrix builds for all target platforms
Pin Qt version — do not use `latest`
Cache Qt install (saves ~3 min per build)
Cache dependency installs (Qt, vcpkg, pip, npm)
Never cache build artifacts across releases
Artifact names include platform and version: `project-0.1.0-linux-amd64.deb`
banned: Builds from dirty worktrees or local build/ directories
Secrets in workflow files — use repository secrets only

title: Package Formats
subtitle: Platform-specific packaging — DEB, RPM, MSI, DMG, tar.gz, APK, IPA
rules: One package = one app (no bundling unrelated tools)
Include LICENSE in every package format
Version from git tag — single source of truth
Use CPack for dual DEB+RPM generation from same build
GUI apps get Start Menu shortcut
CLI apps add install dir to PATH
Set `UpgradeCode` GUID once — never change it
GUI apps use `.app` bundle inside DMG
AAB for Play Store, APK for sideload/direct distribution
Sign with release keystore (never debug keystore)
Use provisioning profile for distribution (App Store or Ad Hoc)
Manage certificates and profiles via CI secrets
banned: Hardcoded versions in package metadata (derive from tag)
Files in `/opt/` unless self-contained bundle with justification
Writing to `C:\Program Files` without proper permissions
Tar bombs (files extracted to current directory without wrapper dir)
Unsigned DMGs for distribution (Gatekeeper blocks them)
Hardcoded signing credentials in build files
Manual code signing on developer machine for releases

title: Private-to-Public Publishing
subtitle: Separate private dev repo from clean public release repo
rules: Private repo holds ALL code — source, tests, proj/, docs, dev scripts
Public repo holds ONLY distributable content — source, build config, LICENSE, README
Public repo can be open-source OR private/commercial
Use `bin/publish.sh` to sync private to public repo
Script uses rsync with explicit excludes — no manual copying
Always review diff in public repo before committing
Tags trigger CI release builds (tag pattern: `v*`)
MAJOR = breaking changes, MINOR = new features, PATCH = fixes
banned: Dev scripts, .claude/, doc/ in public repo
Test suites in public repo (unless library with user-facing tests)
Manual version bumps in multiple places — single source of truth

title: UI-First Workflow
subtitle: Start with UI, work backwards to endpoint — every step visible and testable
rules: Visible result in UI (screen or flow can be demonstrated)
A test or manual reproducible checklist per step
Clear notes about next step and dependencies

title: IPC Contract
subtitle: Unix socket + JSON-RPC 2.0 — shared by all service layers

title: IPC Contract — Unix Socket + JSON-RPC 2.0
subtitle: Shared by all service layers (Python, Node.js, Rust)
rules: Bind to `127.0.0.1` by default; expose to LAN only when required
Use firewall rules to restrict inbound connections
Add authentication if exposed beyond localhost
Consider TLS or SSH tunneling for remote access
All application-level results must follow ACK pattern
Do not mix error styles inside `result`; protocol errors go to `error`
MCP endpoints are still JSON-RPC over Unix sockets
MCP methods must follow the same ACK result pattern
Each JSON-RPC message is a single line
The receiver must ignore blank lines
Messages must not contain unescaped newlines

title: Keyboard Shortcuts

rules: Terminal emulators (VTE) intercept Ctrl+C/V — use Shift modifier

Only assign shortcuts to commonly-used actions
Always use the standard shortcut if the function matches

title: Pointer and Touch

Hover MUST NOT reveal essential actions or information (inaccessible on touch)

banned: Referencing specific devices in UI text (no "click", use "select"/"activate")
